Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Tolerance-Enforced Simulation of Stochastic Processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
High performance computing of continuous random structures arises in a large body of scientific and engineering investigations. For example, these structures are used in environmental models for floods in different geographical areas, which are subject to random measurement errors. They are also used in the prediction and mitigation planning of potential disasters. However, these random structures are impossible to capture in a computer without incurring bias, due to their continuous nature. This research project investigates a new framework for the numerical analysis of continuous random structures. It achieves stronger error control, compared to current state-of-the-art methods, at basically the same computational cost. If successful, the framework and algorithms to be investigated will facilitate analysis and performance evaluation of fundamental random structures of interests to a broad community of scientists and engineers. To enhance the broader impact, the Principal Investigators will train graduate students through research and integrate the results from this research into new graduate courses in scientific computing.

This project investigates a new Monte Carlo framework for continuous stochastic structures (such as differential equations and random fields). The main innovative feature of the framework is the ability to approximate a continuous random object by a fully simulatable (typically piece-wise constant) object with a uniform error bound in the path space with 100% certainty. The error bound is user-specified and can be sequentially refined. Research projects involve developing simulation algorithms for fundamental random structures of interests. These include: Gaussian random fields, Levy processes, fractional Brownian motion, max-stable fields, etc. The algorithms are scalable in the sense of being easily extendable to more complex models by applying the continuous mapping principle with quantifiable error analysis. An important aspect of the methodology is the connection established between Monte Carlo simulation and the theory of rough paths in the setting of stochastic analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary research goal of this project is to investigate a novel class of stochastic simulation procedures that aim at strongly approximating a wide range of continuous random objects. The random objects we studied are widely applied science, engineering, and business, but are impossible to fully construct in a computer without incurring some bias/error due to the continuous nature or the infinite time horizon involved. The algorithms developed not only have strong error guarantees and optimal complexity, but can also be refined sequentially. This tolerance enforcement feature allows one to combine these algorithms with other advanced simulation techniques to gain further efficiency and achieve exact sampling in several important applications.

In pursuit of the research objective, tolerance-enforced simulation algorithms (also known as epsilon-strong simulation algorithms) have been developed for some fundamental continuous stochastic processes such as stochastic differential equations and fractional Brownian motions. These processes are extensively used in biology, physics, and environmental science. However, very few closed-form expressions are known for performance measures based on functionals of these processes. Thus, simulation-based numerical methods have been the main workhorse to study them. The algorithms developed in this project provide new numerical tools with high efficiency and strong error control in this domain. 

The simulation techniques developed in this project have also been applied to achieve exact sampling for the stationary distribution of queueing systems and the all-time maximum various processes. These models are widely used to study communication/computing systems and service systems. The newly proposed algorithms provide more accurate ways to evaluate and optimize the performance of these systems. In the process of developing the simulation procedures, new theoretical results about properties of several important stochastic processes have also been developed. These results can be applied for uncertainty quantification in other numerical algorithms and provide important insights for the development of advanced Markov Chain Monte Carlo Algorithms in Big Data applications.

The project’s education goal includes training graduate students and developing new course materials. Several Ph.D. students have been actively involved in the project. New classes, which provide students with a modern perspective on computational tools in the era of growing computational powers, have been incorporated into existing courses. The projects also provide undergraduate research opportunities. The undergraduate students involved continued pursuing their Ph.D. degrees in STEM fields.
